rename.from: Split chunk fails to load with undfined hash
rename.to: Split chunk fails to load with undefined hash

body: Does this occur for a full build, watch build or with HMR?
@maclockard Can you create minimum reproducible test repo?

This happens for both a full build and watch. However, it only happens when I set NODE_ENV=production.

I spent a bit longer stepping through the webpack build, and it seems as though chunk 63 doesn’t have the requesting chunk listed as a parent. It also only seems to happen when I have 2 or more entry points.

I don’t think I can make a minimally reproducible example since the application I encounter this with is very very large and has many dynamic imports. The total number of chunks we end up with is nearly a 100. If we lower how much it chunks, we no longer encounter this problem.
any thoughts of potentially problematic steps of the compilation? I can try to step through and see whats going wrong
@maclockard no, it is hard to debug without minimum reproducible test repo

Unfortunately this only seems to happen in more complex cases with lots of chunks and dynamic imports :(

I’m trying my best to step through and find where something may go wrong. I think the module to chunk mapping may be correct, but not the chunk to child chunk mapping. 

Which file is the chunk to child chunk mapping made? Is this determined in the splitChunkPlugin or should I try to start debugging elsewhere?
@maclockard there are a lot of places in code where something wrong, or create minimum reproducible test repo as i written above, or start to debug line to line in you build

@evilebottnawi @sokra what ended up being the solution to https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/7061 ? seems like it may be the best place to start debugging so I can verify if its the same issue or not
@maclockard issue not related to your problem, no solution, it was bug

issue.title: WebpackDevServer API - HMR with async chunks when doing code splitting results in inconsistent chunk names (which makes GET calls to undefined.js)

repository.name: webpack
repository.description: A bundler for javascript and friends. Packs many modules into a few bundled assets. Code Splitting allows for loading parts of the application on demand. Through "loaders", modules can be CommonJs, AMD, ES6 modules, CSS, Images, JSON, Coffeescript, LESS, ... and your custom stuff.

issue.body:
**Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?**

Regression bug - as described here: https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/433#issuecomment-286803302

**What is the current behavior?**

When adding HMR support to a project that has async chunks (was imported using `syntax-dynamic-import`) webpack does not keep the same name of the changed chunk. Therefore calls to `x-undefined.js` are being made.

For some reason everything seems to be working only when also adding `NamedModulesPlugin` which is according to the docs optional. It seems it's actually mandatory.

**Important Note:** I did NOT test it using the CLI option. Everything has been tested using the `WebpackDevServer` API.

**If the current behavior is a bug, please provide the steps to reproduce.**

Just add an HMR support to a project by adding:

```js
    filename: '[name]-[chunkhash].js',
    chunkFilename: '[name]-[chunkhash].js',
```

```js
config.entry.application.unshift('react-hot-loader/patch');
config.entry.application.unshift('webpack/hot/dev-server');
config.entry.application.unshift(`webpack-dev-server/client?${config.output.publicPath}`);
```

```js
// HMR (Hot Module Replacement) plugins
config.plugins.push(new webpack.HotModuleReplacementPlugin());
```

Add `hot: true` to the `WebpackDevServer` configurations.

The above fails.

Now, try also adding:
```js
config.plugins.push(new webpack.NamedModulesPlugin());
```

Now everything is working again.

**What is the expected behavior?**

The expected behavior would be that HMR will work without the need to add `NamedModulesPlugin`.


**Please mention other relevant information such as the browser version, Node.js version, webpack version and Operating System.**

Webpack version: 2.3.3
Node.js version: 6.10.1
OS: macOS

body:
**This issue had no activity for at least half a year.**

It's subject to automatic issue closing if there is no activity in the next 15 days.

> @maclockard issue not related to your problem, no solution, it was bug

Does anyone fix it? Is it a bug really?

@vuchan I ended up changing around the order of our dynamic imports and the issue went away. Which kinda sucks since it means this issue is very very build dependent.

Unsure if its been fixed in newer versions of webpack since you can't really directly test it, only way would be going back to that commit and bump webpack's version. I don't have access to the repo I was running into this with, so I can't check.
